entry.title: Expanding Data Federation for Broader Coverage with the New Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) has played a pivotal role in data federation, serving as a cornerstone for positioning SAP HANA Cloud as a single gateway to all data. As highlighted in my previous blog, Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud, SDA has also established itself as the core component for leveraging the full potential of data in the context of Clean Core.

Nevertheless, due to its limited protocol boundary to ODBC and REST, along with restrictions on running third-party drivers within the SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud, the supported scope of remote sources has been limited in SAP HANA Cloud.

This limitation has been complemented by SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) through its JDBC-based adapters, as it also supports data federation, even though SDI is primarily designed for real-time data replication. However, customers must deploy and operate Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) separately in an on-premise setup.

In this context, I'm pleased to announce that, starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, SDA now supports Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake as two new remote sources via a new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

In a nutshell, the new Data Access Agent was developed with the following three key characteristics.

  • Fully managed and secure: Like the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, this new Data Access Agent can be provisioned and deprovisioned in SAP HANA Cloud Central or via the Cloud Foundry Command Line Interface (cf CLI), but it operates separately. This separation helps ensure the SAP HANA database remains secure, as the Data Access Agent runs as a physically separate instance.
  • Greater flexibility: While the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST, this new Data Access Agent supports JDBC-based adapters. These will allow leveraging not only existing SDI adapters but also new third-party driver-based adapters.
  • Simplified operations: As this new Data Access Agent is managed by SAP in a cloud-native manner, the configuration and monitoring processes have become significantly more streamlined and user-friendly.

The good news is that support for remote sources to Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning. As described, since this new Data Access Agent introduces new possibilities for connecting to remote sources with different protocols, there are plans to support additional remote sources for data federation, including SharePoint in Microsoft 365, Google Sheets, and more.

However, please note that although this new Data Access Agent supports new JDBC-based adapters, it only supports data federation and snapshot replica toggling within the virtual table interface. That is, trigger-based real-time replication, like SDI, is not supported.
  

Getting Started with Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud

The first step to configuring remote source connections with the Data Access Agent is to ensure that the BTP subaccount is entitled to the service plan hana-data-access-agent. This is a prerequisite for using the Data Access Agent.

 

Create Data Access Agent:

If the service plan is correctly entitled, you can view and use the new Data Access Agent menu in the multi-environment edition of SAP HANA Cloud Central.

Now, you can proceed with the Create Data Access Agent button to provision a new Data Access Agent by entering its name and selecting one of the four preset size options.

The size of the Data Access Agent will depend on the workloads, and its capacity units (CUs) consumption will vary based on the selected size.

Please refer to the links below for further details, including sizing guidelines. Additionally, you can use the SAP HANA Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator (to be updated soon) to simulate the expected cost of a Data Access Agent for each size and monthly activity, even though the total estimate is already displayed on the right side of the above screen.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Setting Up the Data Access Agent

Once the name and size are decided, the next step is to register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud.

To register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, the corresponding SAP HANA database must be up and running. Additionally, the Data Provisioning Server must be enabled as a prerequisite. Another prerequisite is that the version of the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud must be QRC 02/2025 or later.

Otherwise, it cannot be selected or registered. The reason for being unable to register is also shown in the Details column.

Another important consideration is that a single Data Access Agent can only be registered to one SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. Once registered, the registration cannot be changed to a different SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. This means that for another SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, a new Data Access Agent must be created from scratch. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents, if needed.

After selecting the SAP HANA database instance to register, the next step is to enable adapters to access remote sources.

In the first release of the Data Access Agent, two adapters are available, as mentioned above. One is the AzureSQL adapter, which is used for accessing the Microsoft Azure SQL Database. The other is the Snowflake adapter, which is used for accessing Snowflake.

Adapters can be enabled or disabled later, even after the creation of the Data Access Agent. As previously mentioned, many more adapters will become available in the future.

Alright, that’s all for creating or provisioning a Data Access Agent.

Once the Data Access Agent is up and running, everything is set for creating remote sources and virtual tables. This process is not new and is essentially the same as using SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) or SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).
 

Create a remote source:

-- create a remote source to Snowflake
CREATE REMOTE SOURCE "Snowflake" ADAPTER "Snowflake"
AT LOCATION AGENT GROUP "demo-daa"
CONFIGURATION 'url=https://<myorganization-myaccount>.snowflakecomputing.com;
database=<database_name>;account=<account_name>;auth_type=Password'
WITH CREDENTIAL TYPE 'PASSWORD' USING 'user=<user_name>;password=<password>';

The above example shows how to create a remote source for Snowflake using the CREATE REMOTE SOURCE statement.

Similar to other SDA or SDI remote sources, it can be created using the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI, and remote objects can be retrieved.

Since the syntax and parameters for creating a remote source vary depending on the remote source, please refer to the links below for further details.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create an Azure SQL Remote Source
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Snowflake Remote Source
     

Create virtual tables:

Once the remote source is created, virtual tables can be created using either the CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE statement or the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI.

However, since creating virtual tables and generating statistics are essentially the same as with other SDA adapters, I will not cover these topics in this blog. Please refer to my previous blog or the links below for more information.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Virtual Table
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create Statistics on a Virtual Table or Linked Database
     

FAQs

Q: Do you have plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent, similar to SDI? If so, will SDA replace SDI?
A: No, there are no concrete plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent. As described, the Data Access Agent is intended only for data federation.

Q: It sounds like this new Data Access Agent is a cloud version of DPAgent. Is that the right understanding?
A: The new Data Access Agent can, to some extent, be logically regarded as a cloud version of DPAgent, but it is solely for data federation, as explained. It has been adapted and enhanced to support completely new remote sources, such as Snowflake. Furthermore, support for SharePoint in Microsoft 365 (e.g., list and Excel worksheet), Google Sheets, and more will follow. These remote sources have never been supported via SDI and DPAgent, although SharePoint has been supported for specific formats, such as CSV.

Q: It seems that with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, two new adapters can be enabled with the Data Access Agent. Does enabling an adapter incur additional costs?
A: No, enabling adapters does not incur any additional cost. In other words, regardless of how many new remote resources SAP supports by introducing new adapters via the Data Access Agent in the future, they will not incur any additional cost. Customers only need to pay for running the Data Access Agent itself.
However, the recommended number of adapters may vary depending on the size of the Data Access Agent. To ensure performance and efficient resource utilization, we plan to provide guidance or impose restrictions on the maximum number of adapters based on the size of the Data Access Agent if more adapters are introduced in the future.

Q: What will happen to the existing native ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters? Will they be discontinued or replaced with the new Data Access Agent-based adapters?
A: No, the existing native built-in ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters will continue, and even new remote source support can be introduced as a native built-in ODBC or REST-based SDA adapter. SAP will choose the best protocol when introducing support for a new remote source for data federation. In other words, newer remote sources can be supported either natively (via ODBC or REST) or through the Data Access Agent (via JDBC).

Q: Do you have plans to support the same capability (e.g., the Snowflake adapter via Data Access Agent) with SAP HANA Platform 2.0? Or can I register this new Data Access Agent with SAP HANA Platform 2.0?
A: No, these features are exclusive to SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud.

Q: Can I use a single Data Access Agent with multiple SAP HANA databases in SAP HANA Cloud?
A: No, as already explained, a single Data Access Agent can only be registered with a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents.
 

Conclusion

In summary, the newly developed Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud significantly enhances secure, flexible, and simplified access to remote data sources in a cloud-native manner. Its fully managed, physically separate service ensures the security of the SAP HANA database while supporting seamless provisioning and operation. With protocol flexibility, including JDBC-based adapter support, it enables integration with both existing SDI adapters and new third-party drivers. Its cloud-native design also simplifies configuration and monitoring, reducing complexity for users.

Support for Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning, with plans to expand to additional remote sources like SharePoint in Microsoft 365 and Google Sheets, further broadening data federation capabilities. However, it is important to note that this new capability focuses on data federation and snapshot replica toggling and does not support trigger-based real-time replication, as SDI does.

This innovation reaffirms SAP’s commitment to enhancing data integration while simplifying cloud-based processes, paving the way for more robust and dynamic data connectivity.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
This series of posts gives an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering our whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP SuccessFactors, as well as covering  innovations in our UI technologies for building great UX.

IIn this first post, we’ll look at the latest UX innovations for the SAP Business Suite that are relevant for more than one product:

  • Joule
  • SAP Work Zone
  • SAP Mobile Start

Before we get started: if you haven’t already seen them, do have a look at the overview of public cloud UX innovations I posted in Q1/2025 (parts 2 to 7 are linked in part 1):

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).

This upcoming series of posts includes Joule and AI UX highlights from individual products within the SAP Business Suite, but for a more comprehensive overview of our recent AI innovations, not just UX related, have a look at:

  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q1 2025.
  • SAP Sapphire Innovation Guide – SAP Business AI.

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP systems, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access our cloud products and providing a seamless flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we’ll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule stand-alone: Joule for Consultants
  • Joule Agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 1: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule “Show me sales commission by agend for model bike sales”, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 1, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 1 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as “What is the total revenue for Q1?” or “Show me sales by region in 2025”.
  • Comparative analysis, such as “Compare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?”
  • Time series analysis, such as “Show me sales by month” or “Show the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months”.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as “Show me top 5 sales by store” or “List the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales”.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 2 shows what this looks like.

 

Figure 2: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking “How many languages does Joule support”. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with “Joule currently supports eleven language officially” and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document “Joule Multi Language Support” is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button “+ New Conversation” at the top, followed by a section “Active” with two conversations and a sectin “Expired” with four. The bottom contains a link to “Settings” and on to “AI Notice”.

You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on “New Conversation”. The old conversation will be listed in the “Active” section, as you can see in Figure 2. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the “Expired” section, as shown in Figure 2. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 3.

Figure 3: Joule expanded to full-screen mode, showing the conversation history sidebar and the chat side by side. Alt Text: The same information is shown as on both screens of Figure 2, since the conversation history sidebar does not overlay the chat, and the chat is shown on the right with much more screen width.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Using the Joule Web Client.

Use Joule in 11 Languages

Figure 3 shows that you can ask Joule which languages it supports, and it will answer with the list of 11 languages. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portugese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese

Joule Stand-alone – Joule for Consultants

In addition to providing Joule embedded in our products, we have a design pattern called Joule stand-alone, which we use for Joule for Consultants. With this pattern, Joule can be started directly, without first opening an SAP product and then opening Joule via the icon in the shell header. Joule stand-alone is opened in full screen, as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 4: Joule for Consultants using the Joule stand-alone pattern. Alt-Text: Joule full-screen, with one active conversation “Can you explaine about SAP Clean Core”, followed by a comprehensive answer, and scrolling options for reading the entire text”.

By supporting this pattern, people can open up Joule for Consultants directly and start asking questions about implementing or extending SAP products. Since in this case Joule is stand-alone, as the name suggests, the conversations you have there are not visible in the Joule instance that is embedded in our products, and vice-versa.

Joule Agents

We are bringing SAP Business AI to the next level via Joule Agents, that can autonomously plan and execute multi-step workflows.

Why do I include this in a section on user experience updates? Aren’t Joule Agents a back-end thing? Well… the reason is simple: Joule Agents significantly enhance the overall user experience, as opposed to the user interface, because the system will do a lot more for you based on your requests. This means that the overall experience you have using SAP goes up a level, since you can get a lot done much more easily than before.

Joule Agents can be triggered from Joule directly, or embedded within applications. These four marketing videos show you examples of agents available today:

  • Finance: Dispute Resolution Agent (1:38 minutes)
  • Procurement: Sourcing Agent (1:48 minutes)
  • Sales and services: Account Planning Agent (1:24 minutes)
  • Human Resources: Performance and Goals Agent (1:34 minutes)

This example for customer service agents goes into more detail:

  • CX Agents (in SAP Discovery Center).

For a general overview of Joule Agents, have a look here:

  • Joule Agents on sap.com.
  • AI Agents in Action (blog post).
  • Envision the Future of Generative AI with SAP's AI Agents (blog post).

Product-specific capabilities

In addition to the above generic capabilities, our products provide a large number of Joule skills for getting your work done more efficiently, as well as a handful of the new agents discussed above. For a comprehensive overview of Joule capabilities, including product-specific skills available today, here’s where to go:

  • Joule Capabilities (a 484 page (!) PDF document from July 11th, 2025, including a list of What’s New)
  • Joule Capabilities (online documentation)

Customer-specific Joule skills

You can now build your own Joule skills using Joule Studio, which has now been made generally available. Read Michael Ameling’s overview blog post:

  • Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation

Joule on Mobile Devices – now for SAP SuccessFactors too

Joule has been available via SAP Mobile Start since Q1/2025 (as announced in this blog post), and is now also available directly from within the SAP SuccessFactors mobile app, supporting these three patterns:

  • Transactional: Joule can handle tasks like requesting time off, updating contact information, and even deleting phone numbers, directly within the chat interface.
  • Navigational: Joule can guide users to specific pages within the app based on their requests, such as directing them to where they can assign team goals.
  • Informational: Joule can access documentation and knowledge bases to answer questions about company policies, HR guidelines, and other relevant information, providing summaries and links to related resources.

Figure 5 shows two examples of the transactional pattern plus one example of the informational pattern (“Can I use my private car for my business trip?”).

 

Figure 5: Examples of Joule on the SuccessFactors Mobile App. Alt Text: The image shows three examples: The first shows the response to the request by a manager “View time off approval”, with the details of one request, including the employee's name, the time-off period, and the type of time-off (vacation). The user can view the details, approve, or decline the request. The second screen shows a conversation where the user asks if they can use their private car for a business trip, and the system responds that they can, providing details on the reimbursement policy. The third screen shows the user requesting one day of vacation leave on March 3, 2025. The system confirms the request and provides the details of the leave, including the start and end times, and the date the user will return to work.

Find out more here:

  • Say Hi to Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile, Powered by SAP Build - Part 1: Unlocking AI for HR)
  • Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile: Getting Things Done with AI...
  • Documentation: Joule Available in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile - May 2025

Further information on Joule

If you want an overview of what’s new, or want to set up Joule in your landscape, have a look at the documentation:

  • Joule documentation (including What’s New, What is Joule?, integration guide)
  • What is Joule? PDF file

For an overview of what is planned, have a look at the road map for Joule in the SAP Road Map Explorer:

  • Joule Road Map.

SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone users and administrators benefit from these recent innovations:

  • New Side navigation for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.
  • SAPUI5 version preview.
  • Mobile Start supports Work Zone, advanced edition.

New Side Navigation

As I announced in April, in my blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), we are introducing some design updates to all our products in the SAP Business Suite to further increase consistency, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products – no unexpected surprises. One of these is the introduction of a navigation menu on the left side of the screen.

SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, is the first product to support this new design. Figure 6 shows what it looks like when the navigation menu is expanded, while Figure 7 shows it collapsed.

Figure 6: Side navigation expanded for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: A screen showing a SAP Build Work Zone screen with a navigation menu on the left with four entries “Central Procurement”, “Global Support”, “My IT Experience” (selected), and “Self Services”. On the right various cards are shown in a section “Employee Information”.

 

Figure 7: Side navigation collapsed for SAP Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: similar to Figure 6, but with the navigation menu on the left collapsed to the width of an icon, with four icons shown representing the four navigation options.

SAPUI5 Version Preview

We have introduced a new feature that allows administrators to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone, two weeks before they are adopted in the productive environment.  Until now, the latest SAPUI5 versions were automatically adopted in production environments, which limited opportunities for early evaluation ahead of deployment.

By enabling the preview setting on specific non-productive sites, administrators can assess compatibility and performance with the upcoming version. This controlled testing environment helps identify and address potential issues, reducing the likelihood of disruptions in production. After the two-week preview period, the RTC version becomes the default, aligning all sites with the latest stable release.

When looking at the sites in the site directory, those sites for which the preview is switched on are indicated clearly, as shown in Figure X.

Figure 8: Site directory with a site where preview is turned on. Alt Text: the image shows a card from the site directory for a site called “Preview SAPUI5 Demo” with a green badge containing the text “SAPUI5 Preview Enabled”.

Read more about this feature in this blog post:

  • Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone.

SAP Mobile Start Supports SAP Work Zone, Advanced Edition

When using SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you can now access your Workspaces or Feed Updates. As with the standard edition, your native and web apps are available within the Apps Screen of SAP Mobile Start, as well as in your Favorites Section on the Start Screen, based on your individual selection. 

Tasks and Notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, are also integrated into SAP Mobile Start: they are shown next to your business tasks and situations in the To-Do sections and in the Notification Center. Figure 9 shows an example with notifications from the advanced edition.

This integration is automatically available to customers with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition or SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone if the SAP Mobile Start toggle is enabled in the Site Manager.

Figure 9: SAP Mobile Start notification center with notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Alt Text: A list of two notifications: “Leave Request”, with a red text “Important” and “2 weeks ago”, and “Invite to Worskpace”, with text “Mustaq Ahmmed has invited you to join the workspace “Help & Support Workspace” and “2 weeks ago”.

 

Note that SAP Mobile Start is not the successor app for the SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app. Find out more here:

  • Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update.

SAP Mobile Start

Beyond providing Joule natively for mobile devices, SAP Mobile Start has recently introduced a number of user experience improvements with their 2.2 and 2.3 releases. In addition to supporting SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, as described above, the main new features are:

  • Completed To-Dos are now displayed too (see Figure 10).
  • Site Switch allows you to directly switch between SAP Build Work Zone sites, without having to go through the onboarding process for each site.
  • The news tile can now also include images (see Figure 10).
  • News feeds that require authentication are supported now.
  • Design updates such as enhanced navigation bar for Apple iPad and a new fresher design for monitoring details on Apple Watch.

Figure 10: On the left, SAP Mobile Start showing completed To-Dos, on the right showing news with an image. Alt Text: On the left, the To-Dos section is selected, showing two To-Do cards, and the top half of a third card. The first one shows Maria Smith requested 180 days maternity leave, the second one that Quality Manager Donna Moore requested €47,600 spend. The right shows the start page, with a section Monitoring apps at the top, with two cards, followed by the News section, with one card listing two news items, the first of which has an image.

To find out more about the above recent innovations as well as what is planned in our road map, have a look at:

  • Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update.
  • SAP Mobile Start Road Map.

Continued soon…

I hope you enjoyed this first part, covering cross-product UX services. I will post part two soon, covering a a large number of UX innovations coming with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori launchpad.

entry.title: Re: validity update in mass changes to purchasing info re...
entry.content:
You need to use the correct excel template format. SAP expects two separate rows for each condition

  • One row to expire the current condition (set Valid To as Current Date – 1)
  • One row to create the new condition (set Valid From as Current Date)


Ensure that both rows have different validity periods and same condition type ABCD. SAP won’t allow overlapping validity periods for the same condition record. If your upload only changes the price but keeps the same validity, it will overwrite instead of creating a new record

entry.title: Re: validity update in mass changes to purchasing info re...
entry.content: Do we need to update New indicator for the new condition? Also can condition group ID needs to be same or different for both lines.

entry.title: Selective Data Transition using SAP Business Transformation Center (BTC)
entry.content:
Selective Data Transition- Overview

As part of the SDT Proces, an SAP ERP Shell System must be created and converted to an SAP S/4HANA Shell System.
 

The conversion follows a structured approach:
 
1️. Shell System Creation
A shell copy of the SAP ECC system is created.
This copy excludes transactional and master data while preserving configurations and repository objects.
SAP Standard Tool-based methods (e.g., System & Client Copy, Landscape Transformation) or SAP Partner Services can be used.
 
2️. SAP S/4HANA Conversion
The ECC Shell System undergoes a technical conversion to SAP S/4HANA, ensuring it is ready to receive selectively migration data.

3️. Selective Data Transition with BTC
The SAP Business Transformation Center analyzes the Source system data using readiness check report and defines which company codes, transformation objects, and historical data should be migrated.
The Digital Blueprint is generated, documenting all scoped data for a controlled migration.
Data transformation is executed within SAP BTC, ensuring a structured transition from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA

 

 

 

 

STEP 1- Shell Creation using LT Cockpit with System Copy Concept

Before we talk about shell creation process, let us see what is the shell system ?

Shell is the system with reduced data volume excluding application data and unnecessary clients.

The shell creation process excludes all clients except the SAP reference client 000, which is fully copied to the target system, including all data such as user master records, cross-client customizing, and Repository data[ including reports, programs, and table structures for all database tables]

The Shell system does not contain the following types of data:

  • Business Client-specific Customizing data
  • Business Client-specific Application data

Shell Creation Procedure

Step (i): Create an Empty Shell System

  • Use the SAP System Copy procedure via Software Provisioning Manager (SWPM).
  • Utilize SAP Landscape Transformation Cockpit (SAP LT Cockpit) to exclude transactional and Master data.
  • Copy only repository objects, cross-client customizing data, and client 000.
  • Ensure the target system is properly installed and configured.

Step (ii): Perform the Client Copy

  • Create and RFC connection from Target system to Source System.
  • Use Transaction SCCL (Local Client Copy) or SCC9 (Remote Client Copy).
  • Select the appropriate profile (e.g., SAP_UCSV).
  • Validate the copy process by checking logs (SCC3).

 

Shell Creation Execution Steps

Task 1: Setting of ENV variables for shell creation. 

Task 2: Export Preparation  using SWPM

Task  3: Table splitting [If required] using SWPM

Task 4: Shell creation process using the LT Cockpit

Task 5: DB instance export and import using SWPM

Task 6: Perform the  Client Copy using the profile SAP_UCSV

 

Task 1:Setting of ENV variables for shell creation. 

         we have to set the below environmental variables as root user at OS level during the DB Export Preparation , Table splitting operation and DB instance export

              export SAP_LT_SHELL_CREATION= TRUE

 

Task  2: Export Preparation using SWPM

During the Export preparation it performs the below

1.Creates the Export structure

Directory

 Description

<export dump dir>/DATA

Contains the STR files generated by R3ldctl

<export dump dir>/DB

Contains the DDL<DBTYPE>.TPL files generated by R3ldctl

<export dump dir>/DB/<DBTYPE>

Contains the EXT files generated by R3szchk (optional)

2.Upon creation of the export structure , it used R3LDCTL, R3SZCHK to create STR and TPL Files

R3LDCTL

                a. Creates the *.STR file [Structure files] which are Database Independent [STR Files have characteristics of all the tables/indexes as specified in SAP data dictionary]

               b. Creates the *.TPL files [Template files] which are database dependent [TPL Files contain the database specific syntax for creating the tables and indexes ]

R3SZCHK

  1. Calculates the size of the ABAP and indexes tables and creates the *.EXT Files.

 

R3LDCTL retrieves information from the DD09L table, extracts the size category and data class information of the respective table information, and update this data in .STR files.

R3LDCTL gathers information from TA<DBS> and IA<DBS> to determine which data class is assigned to which storage unit and records this information in DDL<DBS>.TPL files.

 

Task 3: Table splitting using SWPM

As this System copy process is part of shell creation , so we are able to perform the table splitting for cross client tables only

For example DBTABLOG is a cross client table, so it eligible to perform the Table splitting

So to check whether the table is cross client or not you can follow the below steps

1.Check the table DD02L which contains metadata

2.Check the filed name CLNTDEPEND

                     if Filed value is “c” then it is Client dependent table

                     if Filed value is “ “[blank] then it is client independent table

SAPUptool tool will perform the Table splitting operation

Export preparation with table split operation, generates a file WHR.txt with names of the related tables and

.WHR files with the WHERE Conditions for the table split.

Note:  If you try to perform the table split operation for Client specific tables it will through an error

during the shell creation process in LT Cockpit

 

Task 4: Shell Creation Process using Landscape Transformation Cockpit

Mandatory Pre requisite for Shell creation  ------ Make sure DMIS Add on installed[DMIS 2011]

    1.Login to SAP Source system with client 000 and give the T code : CNV_MBT_SLOP

                    a. Create the Project and sub project

                    b. Create the package :Shell Creation for ERP

2. Once Package is created for Shell creation, execute the below task list, where below task list creates the background jobs to perform an action. We can monitor in  T code Sm37

 

 

Task 5: DB Instance Export and Import

During the export and import , R3LOAD is responsible for Export and import of data from the Database

DB instance Export 

During the export operation, R3LOAD uses the files created by the R3ldctl and R3szchk and creates the below

  1. a. Compressed binary format files .001, .002 etc..,
  2. b. TOC files[Table of Content]
  3. c.  TSK files [Task files]

DB instance Import

During the import operation, R3load uses the  STR files to create the database objects and uses the dump files to populate the target database

Task 6: perform the Remote Client Copy using the profile SAP_UCSV

 

Important Files To Check For Troubleshooting

During the Export operation we have to check the below log files as part of trouble shooting

  • Export_monitor_cmd.properties
  • Export_state.properties
  • ExportMonitor.console.log

 

During the import operation we have to check the below log files as part of trouble shooting

  • Import _monitor_cmd.properties
  • Import_state.properties
  • ImportMonitor.console.log

Location for the below log files

During export operation \tmp\sapinst_instdir\NW<version>\<Database name>\COPY\EXP\AS-ABAP

Ex: if it is Oracle with sap NW version 752-- cd \tmp\sapinst_instdir\NW752\ORA\COPY\EXP\AS-ABAP

During import operation \tmp\sapinst_instdir\NW<version>\<Database name>\COPY\EXP\AS-ABAP

Ex: if it is HANA  /tmp/sapinst_instdir/GENERIC/HDB/DBREFRESH

 

STEP 2-- S4 SYSTEM CONVERSION 

 

STEP 3 -- Selective Data Transition with BTC

Below are the High level steps as part of data selection 

  • STEP 1:  Generating the analysis file from the source system by implementing the SAP NOTES  SAP Note 3112362 & SAP Note 3275056
  • STEP 2: Uploading the source data zip file from STEP 1 to SAP BTC.
  • STEP 3: Creating a digital blueprint out of the uploaded file
  • STEP 4: Understanding the source system data through 'Select Company Code' App
  • STEP 5: Scoping company code and Transformation objects for selective data transitioning
  • STEP 6: Scoping custom Z-objects and data from bespoke application for migration
  • STEP 7: Scoping the scanned tables
  • STEP 8: Confirming the Digital Blue Print
  • STEP 9: Creating a Transformation model for project execution
  • STEP 10: Connect the source ECC System and Target Converted Empty Shell system using Cloud Connector.
  • STEP 11: Feeding this information into the S/4 HANA converted SHELL system.
  • STEP 12: Data migration to target S/4 HANA

 

BTC Integration with Source and Target systems

BTC Connectivity Diagram From Source ECC To Target S4

SAP Business Transformation Center is a cloud native application which relies on the following components:

  • The source system, which utilizes the current ST-PI add-on to enable the data transformation with SAP Business Transformation Center.
  • The SAP S/4HANA system, which contains all necessary subcomponents already shipped within theSAP S/4HANA CORE component.

Each system is accessed from the cloud layer using the SAP Cloud Connector.

The SAP ECC system and the SAP S/4HANA system are connected via OData service bindings from SAP Business Technology Platform.

There is an RFC-based connection between the SAP ECC and the SAP S/4HANA system.

Connectivity Steps From Source ECC to BTC

High level tasks involved with onboarding a new SAP ECC source system to SAP BTC:

1.Ensure that the minimum version requirement as described in question 'What are the restrictions in using BTC for SDT?'  is met.

2.Ensure to apply the SAP note 3443741 in source system.

3.Configure the required OData services in the ABAP source system for SAP Business Transformation Center as described in OData Services .

4.Configure Cloud Connector for the source system in SAP Business Transformation Center as described in Configure Cloud Connector 

5.Connect the ABAP system to cloud ALM using the 'Landscape management' app as described in Connect an ABAP System to SAP Cloud ALM 

6.Maintain the property store in source ECC via the /BDTS/ADMIN transaction as described in Property Store in SAP ECC System 

 

Connectivity Steps From Target S4 To BTC

High level tasks involved with onboarding a target S/4 HANA Shell to SAP BTC:

1.Ensure that the minimum version requirement as described in question for target 'What are the restrictions in using BTC for SDT?'  is met.

2.Ensure to apply the SAP note 3443741 in target system.

  1.  Configure the OData services in the ABAP target system for SAP Business Transformation Center as described in Target OData services 

4.Configure Cloud Connector for the target system in SAP Business Transformation Center as described in Cloud Connector 

5.Connect an ABAP System to SAP Cloud ALM as described in Connect target to Cloud ALM .

6.Create RFC Destination to SAP ECC Source System in target system and maintain the property store in target as described in Maintenance of Property Store in SAP S/4HANA System . This RFC will be used by the migration engine of SAP BTC to pull data packages from the SAP ECC source system  and hence must be maintained in the property RfcDestinationSender in t-code bdts_admin-> Select BDTS_PROPERTIES_SET. Also refer to SAP note 3477261 - SAP Business Transformation Center: Troubleshooting - Setup and Configuration .

7.During the shell conversion process, the upgrade buffer of the system was updated and this must be saved as described in the link Save the Upgrade Buffers .

8.To enable the handling of cloud commands on the ABAP side, the Command Daemon must be  activated as described in Start the Command Daemon 

 

Reference documents

Shell Creation for SAP ERP | SAP Help Portal

Selective Data Transition Engagement (sap.com)

Move to SAP S/4HANA with Selective Data Transition - SAP Community

Troubleshooting for Migration to SAP HANA | SAP Help Portal

Everything about using SAP Business Transformation... - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Duplicate Invoices generated.
entry.content:
Hello Sitaram 

Could you please check the copy controls between delivery and invoice?

At the item category level, there is a field called “POS/Neg. Quantity.” This field should be set to “+” (Positive).

If this field is left blank, the system may allow you to create multiple invoices for the same delivery, as it won’t properly track the quantity that has already been invoiced.

Setting the field to “+” ensures that the system correctly considers invoiced quantities and prevents duplicate invoicing.

Regards,
Satya

entry.title: Re: TM - Delivery Order with reference to Freight Order
entry.content:
If the bgRFC setting is missing, the order based FU will not generate neither, meaning it's not the root cause. Delivery has TM Status tab and Control Key determined, meaning the integration is probably okay. Usually we run report /SCMTMS/CHK_DOC_INT_TM_INTEGR to do initial analysis. If the report just shows 'FU is not assigned', then it will be a FU building relevant issue. Likely, to check the FUBR and identify whether the value of 'Critical Quantity' is passed to TM or not.

Debugging places:

  1. LE-TM integration: /SCMTMS/CL_LE_TM_INTEGRATION=>EXECUTE_TM_UPDATE
  2. FU building: /SCMTMS/CL_FU_BUILDER_CORE=>EXECUTE and /SCMTMS/CL_FU_BUILDER_IL=>CREATE_FUS

entry.title: Intercompany billing: How can price date be taken from Billing date?
entry.content:
Hi All,

We have an issue. We are working with replenishment order, sales organization is company A(Plant A), and the goods will ship from plant B(InterCompany B) to the customer and while VF04, we have some troubles with picking the prices in the intercompany invoice.

Example:

We have 2 condition records
Condition type PI01- 1.10.2023 - 30.09.2024 = 134 usd
Condition type PI01- 1.10.2024 - 31.12.2025 = 121 usd

For the external customer SO below is the scenario, 

1. external customer SO price date is 12.06.2024

2. the delivery is created on 14.04.2025 (PGI date 21.04.2025)

3. the intercompany invoice is created. On item level for the condition type PI01 is placed the pricing date 12.06.2024 =134 usd 

Our requirement is,  inter company billing invoice should pick the pricing condition record from current billing date i,e 28.07.2025 =121 usd. 

And then we thought we can choose a pricing date eg. 28.07.2025 to re-determine the pricing  with 121 usd.  when conduct VF04, so we did some test in testing box, but when we still leave  pricing date field as blank and the billing is doing as expected, picked the current billing date price 121 usd.  , it is different from the situation in production box which picked the old price.


Dear all SAP experts, Hi @Lakshmipathi  Please throw some light on this issue, what is the cause to lead to different result in both boxes, and how can we fulfill our requirement, intercomany billing can pick the pricing date from billing date. 


FYI,
Copy control maintained in VTFL is, this is same in both testing box and production box.
Price type - "G"
Price Source - "Blank"

 

V/06 setting. . same in both testing box and production box.

entry.title: Re: Intercompany billing: How can price date be taken fro...
entry.content:
In intercompany billing, SAP typically determines the pricing date based on Sales order pricing date (if copied), Goods Issue date, Billing date (if no other date is specified). If your production system is picking 12.06.2024 instead of 28.07.2025, it’s likely because the copy control settings (VTFL) are configured to use Price Source A (sales order) and Price Type B (copy manual pricing and redetermine others). This causes the system to retain the original pricing date from the sales order.

To ensure the intercompany invoice picks the current billing date for pricing (e.g., 28.07.2025), Go to transaction VTFL, Select the relevant delivery type → billing type combination (e.g., NL → IV), in the item-level copy control, verify Price Source = C and Pricing Type = B. This ensures the system uses the billing date as the pricing date during invoice creation. In V/06, check that PI01 is configured to use pricing date as the condition record selection date.

Though you mentioned, the configuration is same in both the DEV & PRD, still, check the above areas and if needed, create a new TR to move the same config to PRD.  Sometimes, the related pricing objects may not have updated properly in PRD and importing a new TR will solve that issue.

entry.title: Frequent used CDS Views in Cloud ERP, Public Edition
entry.content:
In this blog, we will introduce several frequent used CDS view with use cases that raised to me in Cloud ERP, Public Edition. Your feedback is invaluable to us. Please kudos this post so we can gauge its usefulness and prioritize further expansion of the content.

Should you have additional use-cases or requirements, share them in the comments—together we’ll enrich this resource into a comprehensive reference. This blog heavily rely on APP Customer Data Browser,  Fiori ID F5746 with different scenarios.

 

Index

I_GoodsMovementCube

I_PURCHASEORDERITEMAPI01

i_materialdocumentitem_2

I_JournalEntry

I_SALESORDER

 

I_GoodsMovementCube

Use case: Is there any standard app that can directly export the relevant purchase orders based on “Purchasing Group + actual posting date”? For example, a list of all purchase orders already posted by a certain buyer between 1 Jan 2025 and 30 Jun 2025.

Solution:

This CDS view is corresponding to APP Goods Movement Analysis with most fields to select from.

First of all there is unfortunately no standard app to achieve the goal so we have a workaround and basically you can follow this procedure to achieve your customized reporting requirement.

Step 1:  APP Customer Data Browser

Click the CDS View tab and key in I_GoodsMovementCube in the search box.

Step 2:  Customize the filter

Extend the filter field according to your need. Here we select two fields: Posting Date in the document and purchasing group

Step 3: Customize the reporting result

Select additional two fields in the setting on the result. You have 102 fields to select from.

Here is the final result you may want:

 

I_PURCHASEORDERITEMAPI01

This CDS View corresponds to APP Monitor purchase Order item

 

i_materialdocumentitem_2

This CDS View has smaller set of field comparing to I_GoodsMovementCube. Eg no purchasing group field so this CDS view is not picked.

 

I_JournalEntry

 

I_SALESORDER

The features covered in this article are based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2508, please refer to the latest information for changes in subsequent versions.

 

My recent blogs:

Advanced Intercompany Sales MTO and Variant Configuration (7DM) in S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

entry.title: SAP Signavio July 2025 Release: SAP Signavio Process Insights and Intelligence
entry.content:
The latest quarterly release of the SAP Signavio Transformation Suite has arrived, delivering new capabilities and key enhancements across Process Intelligence and Process Insights. The July 2025 update introduces smarter ways to uncover inefficiencies, define outcome-driven targets, and turn insights into action. These advancements continue to push the boundaries of process optimization and help you drive meaningful business impact.

Let’s explore what’s new in advanced process analysis and mining!

SAP Signavio Process Intelligence

Root Cause Analysis on Event Graphs

In today’s fast-paced business landscape, true operational excellence demands more than surface-level process metrics — it requires a deep, precise understanding of how your processes actually run. That’s exactly what the new Root Cause Analysis (RCA) on Event Graphs delivers. Building on the foundation of standard RCA, this advanced capability offers a step-level, data-driven view into your operations, identifying exact points of friction such as bottlenecks, rework loops, and inefficient sequences that drain time and resources. Unlike traditional approaches, which often rely on aggregated insights, event graph analysis maps out the true sequence of events, uncovering hidden inefficiencies and providing actionable intelligence for improvement.

Take a real-world scenario: the system might reveal that performing Step A before Step B adds €14 to your production cost. Simply switching their order not only eliminates that cost but actually unlocks an additional €2 in savings — a €16 swing from one small change. This kind of visibility and precision empowers businesses to move from broad assumptions to targeted interventions with measurable impact. Powered by AI, this capability reduces time-to-insight and enables organizations to drive smarter, faster decisions that enhance productivity, cut costs, and unlock hidden value at scale. Root Cause Analysis on Event Graphs redefines what’s possible in process intelligence — shifting the conversation from what happened to why it happened, and most importantly, how to fix it and prevent it in the future.

Root Cause Analysis on Event Graphs

Click here to start a step-by-step tutorial for this feature. Want to read more about Automated Root Cause Analysis? Click here to read a blog post about the capability!

Set an improvement percentage for targets in value analysis

When driving transformation initiatives, the way you define success can make all the difference. Traditionally, business users and process owners have set absolute targets for their value cases — specific numbers they aim to reach for key metrics. But many forward-looking organizations are shifting toward a more dynamic, flexible approach, thinking in terms of percentage improvements rather than fixed values.

Until now, expressing these relative goals required manual effort. With the latest enhancement to SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, you can now gain a more streamlined and flexible way to handle that scenario. As an analyst you can now directly define value case targets as percentage improvements, allowing for quicker, more intuitive modeling of business cases — whether it's reducing your cost per transaction by 10% or boosting throughput by 15%. The system automatically calculates the corresponding absolute values in the background, ensuring accuracy while preserving flexibility. This dual-option capability empowers your teams to align their value modeling with how they actually think about performance improvement — supporting both strategic goal setting and operational precision.

Set an improvement percentage for targets in value analysis

 Click here to start a step-by-step tutorial for this feature.

Snowflake Key Pair authentication

As organizations increasingly rely on cloud-based platforms for analytics, data security and compliance have become central to sustainable digital transformation. Recognizing this, SAP Signavio now supports key-pair authentication for Snowflake, offering a more secure and future-ready method of connecting to one of the most widely adopted cloud data platforms in the enterprise space. This enhancement goes beyond traditional basic authentication by introducing a robust, standards-aligned authentication option that strengthens access control and safeguards sensitive process data pipelines.

With this upgrade, organizations can seamlessly ingest data from Snowflake into SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, while ensuring they remain compliant with Snowflake’s evolving security protocols. Key-pair authentication not only helps maintain uninterrupted connectivity but also delivers enterprise-grade protection — giving your IT teams and analysts the confidence that their analytics infrastructure is both secure and aligned with modern best practices.

Snowflake Key Pair authentication

 

SAP Signavio Process Insights

Value Analysis: Ariba Process Performance Indicators

Unlocking value from procurement processes is no longer a guessing game — it’s now a data-driven discipline. With newly enhanced support for SAP Ariba solution data, organizations can now uncover high-impact opportunities across their procurement landscape. This includes visibility into four key performance indicators: unpublished contract workspaces with past effective dates, delayed purchase requisition items, overdue purchase orders, and unresolved supplier invoice exceptions. By quantifying the monetary impact tied to these inefficiencies, teams can move beyond surface-level tracking and make informed decisions that prioritize the highest-value improvements. Whether reducing delays, addressing supplier exceptions, or tightening procurement compliance, this capability empowers process and procurement leaders to drive focused, results-oriented optimization across the entire source-to-pay journey.

 

Want to know more about this release? Check out the highlight blog post and see what else we prepared for this release over the entire SAP Signavio Transformation Suite!

We are looking forward to seeing you on the SAP Signavio Community to share feedback, questions and discuss with your peers! This is your space!

Please feel free to share your questions around the release or feedback in the comments with us. You can also reach out to us via the SAP Signavio Community or alternatively watch our Release Webcast on-demand.

entry.title: Re: Process Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store
entry.content:
@philippeaddor thanks for reporting this! yes, it looks like a bug - there is a limit of the Data Store Name - the maximum length allowed for the data store name is 40 characters. We use the fixed suffixes "_Retry" or "_NoRetry", so we need to ensure that the whole Data Store names does not exceed 40 chars when we append those suffixes. We check if Pid or RetryDataStore parameter exceed 34 or 32 chars, and if yes - we have to truncate them to add the suffix (2 scripts: readInterfaceRestartConfFromPD.groovy and readInterfaceNoRestartConfFromPD.groovy lines 30-47). So this truncation is done by "Custom Error Handling with Data Stores" IFlow.
Then Restart job reading Partner Directory data and apparently we append the suffix without check of the Data Store Name length (without truncate). We will provide a fix for this. The workaround in the meantime is to set the restart Data Store in Partner Directory with the name shorter than 32 chars.
thanks for testing it and let us know in case of any further findings.

entry.title: Gaining Operational Insights with the SAP LogServ Workbook on Microsoft Sentinel - Part 4
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Following our previous deep-dives into LogServ usage with Microsoft Sentinel for SAP and customization, let's explore the operational insights available through Sentinel's built-in workbook for SAP LogServ monitoring.

Near real-time visibility atyYour fingertips

The SAP LogServ Insights Dashboard on Azure transforms raw log data into actionable intelligence. Navigate to Microsoft Sentinel > Workbooks > Templates and locate the pre-configured dashboard. 

 

Save to your workspace and open to get started. Make sure to select the Log Analytics workspace powering your Sentinel tenant first.

 

 

Key metrics that matter

The workbook provides comprehensive monitoring across four critical dimensions:

  • Total Events: Track log ingestion volumes (4M events shown)
  • Active Systems: Monitor connected hosts (36 active systems)
  • Data Freshness: Near real-time status indicators with color-coded alerts
  • Log Distribution: Understand log ingestion patterns across your SAP landscape components

The Log Volume Timeline reveals ingestion patterns, helping identify peak usage periods and potential anomalies. Notice how the 24-hour view shows consistent data flow with the characteristic SAP workload patterns.

Pay attention to the status legend: Fresh (green), Recent (orange), Older (red), and Stale (dark red). These indicators help SAP Security and SOC teams quickly assess data currency - critical for incident response.

The workbook automatically refreshes, ensuring your security operations center maintains current visibility into your SAP RISE environment's log ingestion health.

Proactive Alert Configuration

Transform workbook insights into actionable alerts using the Create Alert Rule button visible above the timeline. This creates Azure Monitor alerts directly from your LogServ metrics, enabling threshold-based notifications for critical scenarios like data ingestion anomalies or system connectivity issues. Configure alert rules to monitor total event volumes, data freshness status changes, or active system counts falling below expected baselines.

Azure Monitor's alert engine integrates seamlessly with action groups for email, SMS, Microsoft Teams, or webhook notifications to your operations team. For detailed configuration guidance, reference the Azure Monitor alerts documentation.

 

For those of you who prefer PowerBI for dashboarding...

See this Microsoft Learn article how to craft a dashboard from the Microsoft Sentinel queries for SAP LogServ.

 

Final Words

That’s a wrap🌯. You saw today how to observe log ingestion health and use data freshness indicators for your SAP LogServ solution in Microsoft Sentinel. The built-in views are easy to extend and customize for your own individual needs.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

What visuals are most helpful for your daily operations? Do you want special breakdowns for HANA database, and proxy components like the SAP WebDispatcher? Let us know in the comments or reach out directly.

Cheers Martin & Hemanth
